title: Electron Tomography Finds Three-Dimensional Chromatin Packing Domain Structure in Single Cell Different from Topological Associated Domains
content: The intricate three-dimensional (3D) organization of chromatin structure plays a pivotal role in essential cellular activities such as gene expression, DNA repair and transcriptional regulations [1, 2]. Advances in nanoscale imaging have shed light on chromatinâ€™s organization into packing domains (PD) with radii ranging from about 50nm to 200nm [3, 4], providing crucial insights into the 3D architecture of chromatin. Among various imaging techniques, electron tomography stands out for its unrivaled resolution in 3D [5]. Combined with ChromEM staining [6], a technique that applies Click-EM labeling with the photo-activation of DNA intercalating dye DRAQ5 to double-stranded DNA, electron tomography allowed an unprecedented visualization of chromatin structure. However, the method remained low throughput and is not suitable for multiple cell studies.
